newsitem.title: CYPRUS: UN peacekeepers investigate Cyprus shooting.
newsitem.headline: UN peacekeepers investigate Cyprus shooting.

text.p: United Nations forces in Cyprus are investigating shooting on the ceasefire line dividing the island and the felling of a Turkish flagpost on Monday morning, officials said.
"The only facts we have until now is that shots were fired and a flagpole right behind the Turkish forces position on the ceasefire line snapped." a U.N. source told Reuters.
"How this happened is still a matter for investigation," the source added, refusing to specify which side the shots came from.
The Greek and Turkish Cypriot sides immediately blamed each other for the incident, which occured in the western area of the "green line" that divides Nicosia.

"Around 4 a.m. (0200 GMT) this morning three men were seen attempting to lower the Turkish flag around 40 metres (yds) from the front line of Turkish Cypriot security forces," a Turkish Cypriot military spokesman told reporters.
He said a Turkish Cypriot sentry fired warning shots and the three men were seen running toward Greek Cypriot military positions.

Cypriot government spokesman Yiannakis Cassoulides said officials were not aware of any suspicious movement: "We have absolutely no information of any provocation from our side either by the national guard or by civilians."
Cassoulides said a solar heater and a car were hit. He said U.N. officers inspected weapons of Greek Cypriot sentries and ascertained they had not been fired. A U.N. spokesman declined to comment.
Tension has been high since August, when two Greek Cypriots were killed by Turks and Turkish Cypriot civilians during a buffer zone protest against the division of the island.
A month later a Turkish Cypriot sentry was shot dead at the ceasefire line and a retired Greek Cypriot fireman was subsequently shot dead after straying into Turkish-held positions.
Turkey occupied the northern third of Cyprus shortly after a brief Greek Cypriot coup engineered by the military ruling in Greece in 1974.
